Meet my ex-CEO, Ayman Al-Abdullah.He joined AppSumo in 2016, and took the company from $3M to $84 million per year in revenue in only 6 years.Now, as a CEO coach, Ayman helps 7-figure CEOs get to 9-figure by working less.Hereâ€™s his story:==Before joining AppSumo, Ayman had started a few businessesâ€“but struggled to get them off the ground.So he took an internship at an accounting firm.But immediately... he knew it wasn't for him.Luckily, Ayman Al-Abdullah parlayed that experience into a position at Microsoft, where he worked for 3-4 years.He was part of a rotational program and loved that he got to learn new skills.But eventually, the pull of entrepreneurship was too strong to ignoreâ€¦â€œIf you want to be an entrepreneur,â€ Ayman said.â€œThe best way to learn is to work for an entrepreneur you respect and admire. Itâ€™s better than any MBA or anything you can learn on your own.â€Before leaving Microsoft, Ayman recorded two pitch videos.First, to be Sam Altmanâ€™s chief of staff (he was CEO of YC at the time), and second, to me.Ayman's pitch video: https://t.co/ONiIDAtVZ3We started Ayman on a 2-week trial. He had to close 2 deals in 2 weeks.(We still have people do trials to this day)Even though he was still working at Microsoft fullâ€“time, he crushed the trial and we hired him.Ayman was living in Seattle at the time, and moved to Austin with just the stuff in his backpack (this was in 2015, before moving to Austin was the cool thing to do).â€œIn the first year, our only goal was survival,â€ Ayman recalled.â€œEvery profit we made at AppSumo went straight to funding SumoMe. It was just me running the show, and hiring help seemed impossible.â€So Ayman got creative:He paid an intern $15/hour to take repetitive work off his plateâ€”so he could focus on sales.That decision alone doubled the business.Donâ€™t just work hard. Work smart.Before Ayman, we were stuck around ~$5M in revenue. Under Aymanâ€™s leadership, AppSumoâ€™s revenue skyrocketed from $5M to $70M in six years.But Aymanâ€™s proudest accomplishment is the team:â€œMost tech companies have an 18-month turnover. At AppSumo, we have a leadership team thatâ€™s been in place for over 6 years,â€ Ayman said with a grin.And in 2021, we were rated the #1 place to work in Austin for tech.Now Ayman is a CEO coach helping 7-figure CEOs get to 9-figures.5 pieces of Ayman's advice for aspiring CEOs:1- Get clear about what you wantStarting a business (0-1) and scaling a business (1-n) are completely different ball games.Most founders are better off selling their company or hiring an operator.If youâ€™re determined to keep your company, Ayman advises first defining what success means to you:â€¢Â Do you want 100s of employees?â€¢Â Do you want more of a lifestyle business?â€¢Â Are you chasing a big IPO?==Looks like I reached the word limit... ğŸ˜…Read the full article (or listen to our full conversation) here:https://lnkd.in/emvvq-bT

I was employee #30 at Facebook. Then I got fired.For a long time, I was bitter that they let me go.But the lessons I learned from Mark and Facebook helped me build aÂ $100 million/year company.10 lessons I learned from working directly under Mark Zuckerberg:==1) Focus on ONE goalâ€œMark, weâ€™re not profitable. Letâ€™s try selling tickets inside Facebook events,â€ I pleaded.He said no.Then he took a dry-erase marker and wrote on the board: GROWTH.Markâ€™s goal was 1 billion users.Every idea weâ€™d bring, heâ€™d ask, â€œDoes this help growth or not?â€If it wasnâ€™t driving toward that goal, we didnâ€™t do it.You donâ€™t grow fast by doing many things, but by doing ONE thing extremely well.==2) Move fastAt Facebook, it was normal to work 12+ hours a day.Mark constantly pushed us to have a sense of urgency. One of his internal mantras was â€œMove fast and break thingsâ€.â€œUnless you are breaking stuff, you are not moving fast enough.â€ heâ€™d say.We shipped several updates to the site every day.In comparison, companies like Microsoft would take months to write out product details, discuss them in a lot of meetings, and finally build them.As a startup, your biggest advantage against giant companies is speed.==3) Only hire A PLUS playersMark would only hire people he would be happy to work for.Even our customer support team was filled with Harvard PhDâ€™s.The people from Facebook have gone on to help found Asana, Quora, AppSumo ğŸ˜‰, OpenAI, and more.When youâ€™re in a startup, the first ten people you hire are the most critical.Each makes up 10% of the company.If three are not great, thatâ€™s 30% of your company!A startup depends on great people much more than a big company.==4) Treat your employees wellMark recognized that having a work environment you want to work in would appeal to potential employees...And make the existing ones proud to be there (and stay later at night).Facebook did a lot of things that are the norm now:1. A fancy office in one of the most expensive neighborhoods of Silicon Valley2. Hyper competitive salaries3. $1000 office chairs for everyone4. Comped PowerBook and BlackBerry5. Delicious breakfast, lunch, and dinner catered6. Fridge stocked with any drink you can imagine7. All expenses paid company trips to Las Vegas8. Free happy hours every Friday9. Free laundry/dry cleaning service10. Subsidized housing. $600/month if you lived within 1 mile of the office.11. Summer housing/Winter Cabin that anyone could use==5) Scratch your own itchMany people start businesses in a category they donâ€™t know much about or have an interest in because theyâ€™re told itâ€™s â€œhotâ€ or â€œtrendingâ€.At the start, Mark never intended to build a company. He was just trying to help connect people at college.Build selfishly, share selflessly.==Whoops... looks like I hit the character limit.Read the rest here: ğŸ‘‡ğŸ‘‡https://lnkd.in/e_6F_9hs

This is Peter Maldonado.In 2009, he went bankrupt and lost it all.15 years later, his company is making $500M/year selling meat sticks (yes, you read that correctly).My top 9 takeaways from his story:1- Focus on ONE thingBefore declaring bankruptcy, Peter was involved in many things.He bought and flipped houses. He sold real estate. He also started a food company called Frozen Fitness. â€œStretched thinâ€ is an understatement.After he lost it all, he spoke with a mentor who told him the best way to create real wealth was to pick ONE thing and focus on being the best at it.After interviewing many billionaires, Iâ€™ve found that to be true:Larry Janesky â†’ BasementsJohn Paul DeJoria â†’ HaircareMichael Hudner â†’ Shipping ContainersDiversification is for wealth preservation and protection, not wealth creation.2- Make what you wish existedIn 2011, Peter met his future business partner Rashid Ali.Peter told him about his favorite snack as a kid (meat sticks), and his desire to make a healthier version that was high in protein, low in calories, and tasted just as good.Rashid, who was working as a business operations consultant at the time, loved the idea. Just a few weeks later, they started Chomps as a side hustle.When in doubt, solve your own problems. If you are willing to pay for a solution, itâ€™s likely others are too.3- Reverse engineer greatnessWhile Peter and Rashid both had a background in business, they faced one big problem:They didnâ€™t know anything about the meat industry.So what did they do?They went to the store and bought all the meat sticks they could find. Then they looked at the USDA label, found the co-packer, and reached out to them (GENIUS!!)They did the same thing when they were designing their branding. They dissected what their competitors were doing, took the best, put it together, and refined from there.4- It doesnâ€™t need to be perfectWhen I asked Peter what advice heâ€™d give to beginning entrepreneurs, he said, â€œYou donâ€™t have to have things perfect before you bring them to market. Get it out as fast as possible, get feedback, and iterate from there.â€When he started his first food company Frozen Fitness, he spent so much time on the website that he didnâ€™t sell anything through it before shutting the company down.Think NOW, not HOW!!5- Donâ€™t recklessly go â€œall inâ€In Chompsâ€™ first year, they made $35,000 in sales. The following year, they made $100k+.But it was STILL just a side hustle.It wasnâ€™t until they made $400k and consistently brought in profits that they went full-time.This is something Iâ€™ve written about beforeâ€¦Itâ€™s sexy to say you â€œburned the boatsâ€ and went all in.But itâ€™s much simpler (and realistic) to build a side hustle alongside your day job, hit your freedom number, and then jump ship if you want.Read the rest of my top 9 takeaways from Chomps here: https://lnkd.in/eTXg8yMJ

To all those in their 20s who feel like theyâ€™re â€œbehindâ€.This is me in 2003 at UC Berkeley building CollegeUp (a Craiglist alternative for college students).I wasted thousands of dollars (and time) building a product no one wanted.Then the first 10 years of my career:â€¢ Rejected by Microsoft and Google (twice!)â€¢ Fired by both Facebook and Mint after less than a yearâ€¢ Built 10+ startups that didnâ€™t work out (ouch!)Finally, I started AppSumo and have been growing that ever since.It takes timeâ€¦YEARSâ€¦to figure out your career.Donâ€™t get discouraged. Youâ€™re not failing, youâ€™re learning.Keep going. One day youâ€™ll look back and think, â€œDamn - all those tiny failures really did add up.â€~~Follow Noah Kagan for more content like this! ğŸ’š

My #1 regret in life:I wish I had taken myself and dating more seriously in my 20s.5 pieces of Brutally Honest relationship advice that Iâ€™d give to my younger self (so you can avoid my mistakes):1/ Improve yourselfYou have to love yourself before you can expect someone else to.And if you donâ€™t, itâ€™s a BIG ask to imagine a person will love and fix you.The best way Iâ€™ve found is to focus on the things under your control:You can control:â€¢Â Your effortâ€¢ How you dressâ€¢ Who you hang out withThey won't guarantee someone will show up on your doorstep like Uber Eats...But they guarantee youâ€™ll like yourself - and I promise over time someone else will like you too.2/ Be binary about what youâ€™re looking forWhen you ask people what they want in a partner, they all say the same things.â€œFunny. Attractive. Sweet.â€Cool. But a lot of people are those things.Hereâ€™s what works better...Have binary filters:â€¢ Kids or No Kids?â€¢ Jewish or Not Jewishâ€¢ They want to live in BarcelonaSuper black and white.Having more clear filters makes saying no much easier.3/ Be where the fish areInitially, I thought dating a Jewish person was a big requirement for me.So I went to Israel. LA. New York.But after dating a few Jewish women, it turned out that being Jewish wasnâ€™t a big deal to me.The lesson is the same when youâ€™re marketing for your business.Meet your customers where they are.My friend went to Colombia to find his wife. I met my wife in Barcelona.Where does your ideal partner live? Where are you?4/ The Dinner TestA while back, my brother asked me a question that I still remember to this day.He asked, â€œIf you couldnâ€™t have sex with that person, would you still be with them?â€And for all of my past dates, the answer was â€œNoâ€.You have to like your partner mentally.Why? Because you'll have at least 1,000 dinners with them.Itâ€™s important to genuinely enjoy being with your partner, youâ€™ll be sharing many meals together.5/ Donâ€™t settleA while back, I got engaged to a girl because everything was moving in that direction. I thought that was what I was supposed to do.But then my business partner Chad asked, â€œAre you getting what youâ€™re getting or are you getting what you want?â€As adults, we often let society's norms and expectations drown out our intuition.Go to college. Get good grades. Get a â€˜safeâ€™ job. Work 40 hours a week in a boring cubicle. Work until youâ€™re 65+. And save your best adventures until retirement.But deep down inside...We know when weâ€™re settling.Now, I constantly ask myself, â€œHow did I trick this woman into being my wife?â€I feel so lucky to be with Mafe.~~Iâ€™ve failed MANY times over the years. I hated Sam Parr.He was annoying when I first met him, well sometimes he can still be annoying today ğŸ˜†BUT heâ€™s someone Iâ€™ve become close friends with and have been regularly admiring him.Why? Present as a father, prioritizes his marriage and seems to be making a lot of money doing things he loves. No compromises.So on a recent car drive, I asked him how he seems so aligned. Living a life that appears fulfilling.He mentioned he has 3 things he considers in his working life:1- Is it fun?He loves meeting people - created JoinHampton. He had a problem finding accountants / lawyers - created samslist. Wanted to interview interesting people - created MyFirstMillion. He refuses to create or work on business without personal interest.2- Can I make at least 7-figures from it?With all of his projects he thinks before he starts can he make at least 7-figures from it personally. Be mindful of your market size. If youâ€™re going to work hard either way at least be aware of how big the opportunity is.3- Do I have unique expertise or an advantage in doing it?With his new project Samslist he has a large audience of customers / partners that he can easily promote this service. He sold his ranch when realizing he was better at tech. And for his new business launches, they are all related to his zone of influence.Iâ€™d also add a few more things Iâ€™ve noticed from Sam:1- Hire CEOs. With every business Sam finds a CEO to put in place once he gets it going. This frees up his time and he can spend his cycles advising the CEO rather than being one.2- His partner Sara Parr. Sheâ€™s life-upgraded him. This has been such a game-changer for me to find a partner who teaches and supports me on a regular basis.3- No fucks given. I love when Sam calls out VCs harassing people or he chooses to showcase his mother-in-law's pillow company. Heâ€™s not optimizing for an algorithm. I often find myself thinking - what will people think or this wonâ€™t help me get followers but seeing Sam inspires me to just be me.4- Sam still makes the calls. When he was starting Hamptons or Samslist - Sam is the one who starts it and does intensive customer calls to understand the business. I love the intensity and work that heâ€™s willing to put in to get a business started.Thanks for the inspiration Sam Parr ğŸ™‡â€â™‚ï¸

This past year, Iâ€™ve been learning how to be a husband/father, speak Spanish, and improve my leadership.Hereâ€™s my process for learning:1) Have a good reason to learnI learned Hebrew to speak with my dad in heaven.Iâ€™m learning Spanish because my wife and her family speak it.Where do you want to be in 5 years?Write out your goal and put it on your mirror or phone so you see it regularly.When things get tough, remind yourself of your Why.2) Hire coachesWe think our problems are unique. But millions of people have faced similar problems. You donâ€™t have to reinvent the wheel.At @AppSumo, we spend $1M+/yr on coaches and advisors for our team.Who can you find thatâ€™s already gone to the promised land?And if you canâ€™t afford to hire a coachâ€¦ read more biographies.There are million-dollar lessons hidden in $30 books.Biographies give you a unique peek into the lives of great people.Why not learn from those who have come before you?3) Put it on your calendarEvery week in my calendar, I schedule 1 hour to study leadership.I go to YouTube, HBR.org, and read books.Most of the information you need is out there. Itâ€™s about making time to study and integrate it into your life.4) Be patient with the resultsI know that isnâ€™t what you want to hear. We all want to learn a language, be an expert, or top CEO in a week.But realize that this is a journey thatâ€™s going to take you 10 years (or even longer).In school, we spend 15 years learning English.So it's okay if youâ€™re not fluent in another language in 3 months.Itâ€™s not just about learning a skill and never using it.Itâ€™s about integrating that skill into your daily life.And that takes time and patience.5) Practicing vs. PlayingIâ€™ve been playing squash for a while, and I watch a lot of videos to study the gameplay.But thereâ€™s a VERY big difference between playing to have fun - and practicing deliberately to get better.For squash, that would mean practicing backhands over and over and over.Donâ€™t just wing it. Practice.6) Find an accountability buddyEvery Sunday, I email my friend Adam Gilbert with my priorities.Adam will hold me accountable for things that I didnâ€™t do or could have been improved (and vice versa). Iâ€™ve done this for the past 15 years.â€œIf you want to go fast, go alone. If you want to go far, go together.â€7) Follow the Law of 100Most people fail to learn new skills because they quit too soon.â€¢ Put out 100 videos.â€¢Â Record 100 podcasts.â€¢Â Reach out to 100 potential customers. Get your reps in and you WILL see results.Our team created a free tool to help you stay consistent: lawof100.com How to learn anything faster:1. Have a good reason to learn2. Hire coaches3. Put it on your calendar4. Be patient with the results5. Practicing vs. Playing6. Find an accountability buddy7. Follow the Law of 100What else would you add? ğŸ‘‡ğŸ’š Follow Noah Kagan for more content like this!

It wasnâ€™t â€œfame.â€ It wasnâ€™t Twitter followers.It was fun.I started AppSumo because I LOVE getting deals on apps.And I wanted to help other founders and entrepreneurs get great deals too.Itâ€™s crazy how people talk about how much they make at the job â€” or how big their startup is going to be.Zzzzzâ€¦ ğŸ˜´BORING.If youâ€™re not having fun, youâ€™re wasting your time.In 2024, one of my goals is to have more fun.

My newest startup did $60,093+ in 40 days.Itâ€™s our 4th product in the last 3 years on track to generate $1M in revenue in ~12 months.Here's our 5-step process to launch winning products:Last week, I sat down with David Kelly, the General Manager for AppSumo Originals to share how we ideate, build, test, and launch products.Context: The goal of AppSumo Originals products (TidyCal, KingSumo, SendFox) is to introduce people into the AppSumo ecosystem.1) Use Prioritization ChecklistsMany founders and leaders are familiar with the RICE prioritization framework (Reach, Impact, Confidence, and Effort).At AppSumo Originals, we use a 4-step prioritization checklist:1) Hyped AF - Are we hyped AF about this? â€œIâ€™m always surprised and amazed by how many entrepreneurs build things they donâ€™t really want,â€ David said. â€œBut thatâ€™s a recipe for an unwanted and unused product.â€ Scratch your own itch!2) New Buyers - does this serve the customers we want to attract? â€œWe arenâ€™t afraid to look at competitors,â€ David said candidly. â€œCompetition means there is market availability and that we can approach it a bit differently.â€3) Ease of Creation - is this a relatively easy product to create? â€œAppSumo customers have begged for a Canva alternative,â€ David said. â€œBut the complexity is way outside of our wheelhouse. We donâ€™t want to spend years building in the dark.â€4) Word of Mouth - All three of our previous winners had virality baked into the product,â€ David said. â€œWhen people share their TidyCal link, send emails using SendFox, or share a document through BreezeDoc - it introduces the product to new potential customers.â€ GENIUS!!2) Velocity to The DollarThe reason weâ€™ve limited the number of failed startups at AppSumo is simple:We validate the idea BEFORE we fully build it out.Before building BreezeDoc, we asked people if theyâ€™d pre-buy a DocuSign alternative.Once we see enough interest in the idea, THEN we start to build it out.We started working on BreezeDoc at the end of January.â€œWe keep the team small on purpose to start,â€ David said. â€œJust me, a designer, and a developer at first. When the team is too large, we get too many opinions, which leads to inaction.â€3) Work WITH CustomersOur 30-day MVP process has 3 phases:Phase 1: First Beta VersionThe first thing we do is collect a lot of information on our customers. We TALK to them as much as possible (obviously using a TidyCal link ğŸ˜‰)Phase 2: Customer FeedbackFor BreezeDoc, we did about 6 weeks of beta testing and iterating. This is longer than usual, but we wanted to make sure to get REALLY great feedback.Phase 3: Marketing ExperimentsThe goal for the first 30 days was to get 100 new customers.With that, we worked backward to put together a spreadsheet of marketing activities we could do.By the end of the month, we had 189 new buyers. Success!!Post continued in the comments ğŸ‘‡ğŸ‘‡Follow Noah Kagan for more content like this!

Iâ€™ve had a lot of amazing marketing experiences in my career:â€¢Â Helped Facebook scale to 50M usersâ€¢Â Grew Mint from 0 to 1M users in 6 monthsâ€¢Â Currently run AppSumo doing 9-figures in revenueâ€¢Â 100,000 copies of Million Dollar WeekendHereâ€™s how I create a marketing plan:==1) Identify the problem youâ€™re solvingThe #1 question to answer is â€œWhat problem am I solving?â€I donâ€™t do any marketing until I know my product is desired!No amount of marketing will solve a product problem==A few years ago, we built a site called MeetFam. It was an automatic email tool for e-commerce sites. We tried every marketing strategy you could think of:â€¢Â Direct outreach â€¢Â Paid adsâ€¢Â Blog postsâ€¢ Social mediaBut guess what? No one wanted it. I even begged!So how do you know if youâ€™re solving a problem people are excited about?==The Dollar Test:First, are they EXCITED to give you money?If you have to convince them, theyâ€™re not.==2) Identify your ideal customerAt AppSumo, we have customer avatars of who weâ€™re serving.The more specific you are, the better.If you have 0 idea who your customer is. Survey them. I asked my audience for their BEST piece of parenting advice...Thank you ALL soooooo much, it was overwhelming, and felt very loved with great advice. We picked some of our favorite 10 in no particular order.. for all the parents (or parents-to-be) out there:==1- Deal with your own shitWe all have emotional baggage from past experiences.The best thing you can do is make sure youâ€™re good on the inside - so you donâ€™t transfer it on your child.Ryan Holiday==2- Support your womanDonâ€™t make it 50/50. She suffered more to do it, so treat her like a fucking queen.Sam Parr==3- Avoid temptation to get out of the house.For the first month, at least, spend time with your baby & wife and block out the world.Don't travel, don't get on your phone, don't work.This early commitment will help your wife feel safe as her body heals, and builds the family with a stronger foundation.@bandholz==4- Presence > PresentsThe best gift you can give your child is your time - be present, listen, and lead by example.@SleepMoneyMaker==5- Never stop dating your wifeHave a date with your wife at least once a week as soon as you both feel ready and keep that going. Your relationship with her is the foundation on which your ability to be good parents is built.@KonstantinKisin==6- Create â€˜family guidelinesâ€™ to live byâ€¢Â Gilberts donâ€™t break promisesâ€¢Â Kagans donâ€™t quitWhen times are tough, your child can look to these guidelines for guidance.@MyBodyTutor==7- It's your baby.If you don't want someone holding them, then politely tell them to fuck off. In fact, it's OK to not have anyone over for as long as you want.Be patient and respectful while having boundaries.@bandholz==8- Donâ€™t do too much for themThey are going to make messes, fall, fail, try to do things they are not capable of doing, etc.Donâ€™t step and do for them. Coach them. Teach them. Help them, but donâ€™t do it for them.The more your kid realizes they can figure things out on their own, the more confident they will become.@scottreyes==9- You are going to screw upYouâ€™ll lose your shit and yell at them. Youâ€™ll break a promise you made. Youâ€™ll set a bad example.Donâ€™t beat yourself up over it, but more importantly, apologize.Show your kids what it looks like to be accountable for your actions.@scottreyes==10- Enjoy the journeyWhen they cry, your eyes will get wet. When they laugh, you'll smile. The days will be hard, and long, and exhausting.But deeper and more meaningful (If you let them be.)In a blink, your baby will be 1, then 3, then going to kindergarten. Most people never get told that the time between 0 - 5 years old is a peak life experience.But now you have been. Don't waste it.@themichaelcrist==There were SO many golden nuggets - thanks to everyone who shared their advice!! ğŸ™ ğŸ™

Iâ€™ve spent the last 7 years interviewing the worldâ€™s greatest entrepreneurs.5 key learnings (from 10,000 hours of my podcast):1/ Donâ€™t Be The Best, Be The OnlyIn 1993, Kevin Kelly and his co-founders started Wired Magazine. At the time, they faced zero competition. They were the only magazine talking to tech founders - and it was a strong selling point when they pitched advertisers.Many people are familiar with your Zone of Genius - the intersection between what you love, what youâ€™re good at, and what you get well paid for.But Kevin told me thereâ€™s actually a fourth level. Which is, â€œCan anybody else do that?â€So how do you find what only you can uniquely do?Youâ€™re not going to find it by thinking about it. You have to go out in the world and try stuff. Start projects. Experiment. Fail. Reflect. Fail again. And then, and only then, will the fourth level reveal itself.2/ Donâ€™t Burn The Boatsâ€œI thought I was dying, I was hallucinating, I was screaming at the top of my lungs. My wife didn't know what to do.â€In 2018, Justin Welsh was making $500k/year as the VP of Sales at PatientPop. (Impressive!!)But it wasnâ€™t all peaches and cream. As the company scaled, Justin became overwhelmed with more teammates, more revenue, and more problems. And soon enough - it all boiled over.The morning after a company Christmas party, he suffered a major panic attack.Thatâ€™s when he realized he needed to take back control over his life. He quit drinking alcohol. He fixed his diet. And he started consulting to eventually quit his job.Now, Justin makes $5M/year as a solopreneur selling information products.â€œFind an hour each day to grow a side project. Replace 60% of your current income while trending in the right direction. Then make your move,â€ Justin said. â€œItâ€™s almost always a better decision.â€The two paths he recommends:1. Identify what youâ€™re already getting paid for. Build a portfolio of services that mirror the same outcomes. Go out and find companies who need your services.2. Pick something youâ€™re obsessed with. Go find someone whoâ€™s done it successfully. Study the living hell out of them. Do it your way. Then help people who want to do the same thing.3/ Everyone Is Winging ItPaul Orfalea is the legendary founder of Kinkoâ€™s. If you havenâ€™t heard of Kinkoâ€™s, it was a leading retail chain for copying machines in the late 90s.Paul ran the company for 30 years, and FedEx later acquired it for $2.4 billion dollars in 2004!A piece of advice that Paulâ€™s mother gave to him has stuck with me.â€œIn your 20s, try everything. In your 30s, figure out what you do best. In your 40s, make money from what you do best, and try not to do too much in your 50s.â€Too many people beat themselves up because they donâ€™t have everything 100% figured out. But it takes YEARS - even decades - to figure out what you do best.Continued in the comments ğŸ‘‡ğŸ‘‡

Iâ€™m the CEO of a $100 million business.But the first 10 years of my career:â€¢ Rejected by Google (2x)â€¢ Fired by FB after 9 monthsâ€¢ Built 20+ startups that didnâ€™t work out (ouch!)Here are 18 pieces of brutally honest career advice (I wish I knew earlier):1/ Itâ€™s okay to feel lost. When youâ€™re in your 20s, youâ€™re not supposed to know exactly what you want to do with your career. Instead of trying to predict your career path, focus on taking daily action.2/ Take more swings. Early on, you can afford to take more risks because you have fewer obligations. Do free work to get your foot in the door. Fly across the country to meet with an investor. Start the crazy business idea with your roommate. You only need ONE to win.3/ Be the hub. When I graduated, I hosted meetups and conferencesâ€¦even when I didnâ€™t know anyone. The people I helped like Ramit Sethi, Tim Ferriss, and Ryan Holiday ended up helping me 15 years down the line. Ask the smartest people you know, â€œWho is ONE person I should meet?â€™4/ Document your learning online. Creating content is a career cheat code. Iâ€™ve been writing on my personal blog since 2000 (!!) Worst case? You learn how to write and promote your work. Best case? You attract life-changing opportunities.5/ Learn copywriting. Copywriting is not about hitting a word count or writing a five-paragraph essay. Itâ€™s about capturing attention and persuading action. You will never be disappointed by improving your communication skills.6/ Master the art of the cold email. Iâ€™ve been sending cold emails since I was a freshman. The best cold emails: Get to the point. Instantly grab attention. Answer â€œWhatâ€™s in it for me?â€ If you shoot 100 shots, youâ€™re bound to land one hit.7/ Mentors are overrated. The best way to find a mentor? Become someone worth mentoring. Start things. Encounter a problem. Ask for SPECIFIC feedback, not advice. Report back on how you did. Repeat. Youâ€™ll realize you never needed a â€œmentorâ€ in the first place.8/ Build independent income streams. Getting fired at Facebook taught me that EVERYONE is replaceable. Start more side hustles. Youâ€™ll learn more, earn independent income, and maybe even replace your income to go full-time.9/ Give way less f*cks about other people. No amount of money, followers, or acknowledgment will quench your thirst for fulfillment. The people youâ€™re trying to impress arenâ€™t even thinking about you in the first place. Don't prove others wrong. Prove yourself right.10/ Have more patience. In my 20s, I was impatient to get rich and famous. I beat myself up a ton. Thatâ€™s a miserable way to live. You donâ€™t have to be so hard on yourself. If youâ€™re doing the reps, the results WILL pay off. Be impatient with actions and patient with results.Continued in the comments ğŸ‘‡ğŸ‘‡

It's been 30 days since our new SaaS product (BreezeDoc) went live.The results:4,500+ total signups88% paid signup CVR (!!!)$40,000+ topline revenueThis isn't a one-hit wonder either. BreezeDoc is our 5th product in the last 3 years to generate >$20,000 and >1,000 signups within 30 days of launch.It's not magic how we got here. We have a process that many people can copy...Here's what we did:1) It took us 6 weeks to build and launch the product. I think people typically overcomplicate reqs/spec documents. I focus on simplicity, and I put together 16 bulleted features in a Google Doc that I think we needed to make our v1 good enough. I keep the 80/20 Rule in mind. We can always add more later.2) We set a directional goal of buyers â€” and then work backwards. I created a marketing/launch plan spreadsheet with different marketing activities ranging from $0 to $1,000 in cost each (i.e. Product Hunt launch, cold outreach to people using competitors, Meta Ads, etc.) until it added up to my goal. The math landed on 14 activities. Most our efforts were free/unpaid.3) Post-launch, we got 100+ pieces of user feedback... bug fixes, feature requests, and more. It's EASY to say "yes" to everything. It's HARDER to say "no". At first, we handle big bugs that affect the majority of users... and then we move into longer-term improvements. We narrow down to 3-5 key features we want to add 45 days post-launch (prioritized after urgent bugs).After that, we continue our focus on serving our ICP by listening to feedback and organizing requests that align with our vision...And just keep going with consistency to make the product better. ğŸš€

Culture is how people behave when no one is looking.I'm the CEO of a $100 million company.Here's the exact internal culture handbook we use (bookmark this for later):1) This is YOUR companyAfter working at Intel, Facebook, and Mint, I wanted to work with adults who took ownership of their work, could get stuff done, and were a joy to work with.Kids make excuses. Adults take ownership.2) Lead by exampleA few weeks ago, I blew up at someone in a meeting. Doing that says we are okay with yelling at others.I set a poor example for everyone else.What you do becomes the behavior others imitate.3) Double downâ€¢Â When affiliates was working, we hired 5 more people to grow itâ€¢Â When lifetime deals became popular, we did only those type of dealsInstead of chasing new things, MAXIMIZE the things you know work.4) Test, then investâ€¢Â Hiring a new teammate? Iâ€™m the CEO of a $100 million business.But Iâ€™ve tried (and failed) to build 20+ startups before. Here are 10 pieces of brutally honest advice after two decades of entrepreneurship:1/ Leverage your Zone of InfluenceYour Zone of Influence is the intersection between your existing knowledge, skills, and network.To find yours, ask yourself:â€¢Â What do I get paid for in my day job?â€¢ Who do I have access to in my network?â€¢ What hobbies have people commented positively on?You likely have $100,000+ worth of knowledge, skills, and experience RIGHT NOW that others would pay for.2/ Focus on ONE goalOne of the biggest lessons I learned from working directly under Mark Zuckerberg was this:Pick ONE goalâ€¦ then focus relentlessly on reaching it.Markâ€™s goal was 1 billion users on Facebook.Every idea weâ€™d bring, heâ€™d always ask, â€œDoes this help user growth or not?â€I remember pitching him about doing monetization. He grabbed a marker and wrote â€œGROWTHâ€ on the whiteboard.You donâ€™t grow fast by doing many things, but by doing ONE thing extremely well.3/ The best marketing is a great productWhen I was Director of Marketing at Mint, we grew from 0 to 1 million users in 6 months.We tested many marketing strategies - PR, blogs, influencer marketing, affiliate programs, etc.But ultimately, the best marketing is a great product.Marketing was easy because we had a product that customers LOVED, not liked.First-time entrepreneurs focus on customer acquisition. Second-time entrepreneurs focus on customer retention.4/ Buyers buy againWhen I ran my conference business (CommunityNext), I didn't know how to find sponsors.So I looked at who was sponsoring OTHER conferences and reached out to them.Instead of trying to find NEW customers - find the ones who are already spending money.5/ The industry you pick mattersWhen we started AppSumo, there were ~10 SaaS tools. Now, there are 10,000+.Iâ€™ve watched super hard-working people spend years working on ideas in shrinking markets with little to show for it.WHAT you work on matters more than HOW hard you work.A growing market makes business easy. A shrinking market makes business hard.6/ Work backward from your lifestyleIn my 20s, I was obsessed with getting rich and proving Facebook wrong for firing me. But when I became a millionaire...I still found myself chasing money for the sake of money. Sometimes I still do.Far too often, I see entrepreneurs start a business for freedom but get sucked into their business and end up working MORE than if they just stuck with their day job.Donâ€™t trade your 9-5 for a 5-9.7/ Practice LeadershipThe advice Iâ€™d give my younger self is to practice leadership.For example, start by hiring a cleaner.You learn how to agree on the money, make sure theyâ€™re responsible, and check in on them regularly.Follow Noah Kagan for more content like this!Continued in the comments... ğŸ‘‡ğŸ‘‡

Recently, we re-built our hiring process to get A-players.20+ hours later, it worked...For startups, it's CRITICALLY important to get hires right.Too many founders/executives go into hiring with a half-baked plan. (And that's a huge waste of time, energy, and money.)With our new strategy, we hired two senior-level A-players (designer and dev) â€” without breaking the bank.Here's our process:1) Before we started interviewing, I created a six-page document that codified our culture, new hire projects (e.g., "Redo onboarding with less freebies, instead focusing on KPIs"), and the why/goal behind their projects (e.g., "2x SendFox buyers weekly"). This helped me clarify our business wants... and also helped candidates clarify if they would want to work with us. Clarifying responsibilities and metrics is the MOST critical part of hiring... but it's what founders/executives often miss.2) We outsourced our hiring to a LatAM agency called Howdy.com. There are a lot of these nowadays (Hire With Near, RemotelyTalents, and Outwork Staffing are others I've good things about). We gave the agency the six-page culture/wants document to source the best candidates based on our wants. Using a hiring agency saved us time and money (the new hires are half the cost of similar U.S. hires).3) We created an interview scorecard to objectively evaluate. We had eight graded areas, each on a 1 (poor) to 5 (great) scale, that were aligned with our six-page document wants/needs. Some grading areas included: "Culture: Does this person seem a great independent worker and critical thinker?" and "Technical: Do they check all the boxes for our technical languages, or are familiar enough with similar languages to be able to learn? (Laravel, React, Svelte, Bootstrap)?".After all interviews, we had 42+ (!!!) pages of notes from 16+ interviews with 7+ different candidates.Most importantly, we found two strong new team members who have CLEAR projects with CLEAR KPI/OKR alignment. And expectations are aligned.By the way, if you want the six-page hiring guide I created... leave a comment below and I'll send it to you for free. ğŸ“¤

Iâ€™ve met 25 billionaires during my career as a tech entrepreneur and YouTuber.Collectively, theyâ€™ve created over $1 trillion of value for the world.Here are the 6 biggest lessons they shared with me:1- There are no employee billionairesEvery billionaire Iâ€™ve met became a billionaire through entrepreneurship.As an employee, thereâ€™s a cap on your salary. The average annual raise is 3%.But as an entrepreneur? But the truth is youâ€™re not gonna be a billionaire with only a salary.If you want control of your income, start a business.2- Billionaires create their marketWhoever creates the market, takes home the billions.When we started AppSumo, there were ~10 SaaS tools. Now, there are tens of thousands.A growing market makes business easy. A shrinking market makes business hard.You have to be okay with looking â€œfoolishâ€ NOW to be right LATER.What details do you notice that most people donâ€™t?3- They are okay with being boringYou donâ€™t need to be in a sexy market (like tech or AI) to do well.Larry Janesky became a billionaire with basements. What do you have an advantage in?Youâ€™re much more likely to be successful when you follow your energy instead of the crowd.4- Their attitude towards money never changesWhen you think of how youâ€™ll meet a billionaire, you probably think of seeing them off the coast of Monaco in a super yacht and wearing expensive designer clothes.But that couldnâ€™t be further from the truth.When I met Paul Orfalea he was wearing short socks and sneakers.Zuck is notorious for wearing a simple gray t-shirt with jeans.Peter Thiel was using an old iPhone 7 and Hanes socks.Theyâ€™re less concerned with LOOKING rich and more concerned with BEING rich.Money doesnâ€™t change your character, it only reveals it.5- Billionaires got rich doing ONE thingYou donâ€™t build wealth by diversifying. Once you find one that works - DOUBLE DOWN!Diversification is for wealth preservation and protection, not wealth creation.6- Billionaires pay the priceMany of the billionaires I spoke with told me how they sacrificed relationships with their spouse and kids.They also said theyâ€™d give anything to have those relationships back.â€œYou canâ€™t get back the time with family, but you can always make more money.â€Entrepreneurship is NOT just about becoming a billionaire.Itâ€™s about creating your dream life.Not everyone wants to or should become a billionaire.For me, Iâ€™ve never wanted to be a mega-billionaire or own a fleet of yachts.I wanted the freedom to work on stuff I love and be with my favorite people.

My $80M company has over 100 teammates. Here are 8 principles we instill into our culture from our internal AppSumo handbook (that you can steal):1- This is your company.If I had to summarize our entire culture into one point, it would be it. We hire adults that we trust to embrace this mindset.After working at Intel, Facebook, and Mint, I realized what I wanted above all was to work with adults who took ownership of their work, could get stuff done, and were a joy to work with.2- Lead by example.What you do becomes the behavior others imitate.Recently I blew up at someone in a meeting. Doing that says we are okay with yelling at others. Or when I was 5 minutes late to a team sync. That sets a poor example for everyone. These were areas Iâ€™m improving as a leader setting the example.If you want people to give more praise to others, then SET the example and praise often.3- Double down.When something is working, we double down on it.â€¢ Affiliates as a marketing channel was working, we hired 5 additional people to grow this. â€¢ When lifetime deals became super popular, we decided to only do those types of deals. Instead of chasing new things, MAXIMIZE the things you know work.4- Test, then invest.Instead of spending a lot on something unknown, find out if itâ€™s working quickly for a low cost:â€¢ Hiring a new teammate? Start with 1 month paid trial.â€¢ Buying new software? Start with 1 month, not a full year.â€¢ New marketing idea? Start with a small group of customers.Once we can validate our idea on a small scale, then invest big time.5- Ask for forgiveness, not permission.As most companies get larger, rules and policies get put into place.But no one wants to sit around waiting for their bossâ€™s bossâ€™s boss to approve their idea. Good judgment > Good process6- Default to Sharing.Our KPI sheet, board notes, monthly business reviews and budgets are available for all to view.Why? Because people should know how the business is being run. At my previous jobs, this information was always hidden.By sharing the info, people learn more and make better decisions. 7- Feedback is a gift.Feedback is encouraged.If there is a problem, we bring it up respectfully and directly. We donâ€™t go behind someoneâ€™s back and sh*t talk them.Feedback allows us to improve. We arenâ€™t always going to agree. In fact, we often ask others to play devilâ€™s advocate for our ideas so that we know weâ€™re covering all the bases.The best ideas come out of hard conversations and feedback.8- Never forget the taco.As weâ€™ve gotten larger, itâ€™s easy to take the bland, safe route.â€˜Never forget the tacoâ€™ is a reminder to not become lame. That is what culture is at its coreâ€¦ Never forget who you are.Hope this gives you some ideas for your own company culture. ğŸ’š If you enjoyed this, I share more in my newsletter: noahkagan.comCheck out our full AppSumo Culture Handbook: https://lnkd.in/eP3v5rha

Part 1 of 2: My A/B testing process revealed ğŸ“šMy friend Neville Medhora wrote a tweet about how I â€œsplit testedâ€ my way to the color of the cover for Million Dollar Weekend.Here's a deep dive into how we used A/B testing and data to iterate our way to the current cover (and how you can apply it for your business).1- Finish StrongWhether we want to believe it or not, people DO judge a book by its cover. And if they never pick up your book because the cover sucks, theyâ€™ll never get to the good stuff inside.By the time my publishers sent me 50 book covers to review, I had already spent years writing and rewriting the contents of the book. We were getting close to launch, and it would have been easy to just pick one of the covers provided.But my mother always told me to â€œfinish strongâ€ - you always forget how hard you ran after the race is over. Last lap matters most. Why work so hard on your product, only to not do the marketing?When I spoke with James Clear, he told me that he tested 300 different book covers. 300!So I knew that it was essential to have everythingâ€“the title, subtitle, color, font, and graphicsâ€“dialed in.2- Test, Test, then Test Some MoreThe easiest way to improve your business is to ASK. You can do it with data and you can do it qualitatively with customer opinion. Testing should NOT replace you making decisions but inform better decision making.We set up inexpensive FB ad campaigns by running them in affordable countries. In total, we spent $377 on 7.8M impressions that garnered 50k clicks ($.007 a click), targeting men aged 18-65 in China, India, and Singapore who speak English.Then we looked at the clickthrough rate for each cover. The covers that performed the best included the â€˜snapping fingersâ€™ graphic, Million Dollar Weekend with a golden ticket, and Million Dollar Weekend with a calendar.Next, we tested our top results against each other in 5 more iterations of the ad test. The â€˜snapping fingersâ€™ graphic won with a 0.83% clickthrough rate. Nice!3- â€˜Broken Door Problemâ€™I felt confident about using the â€˜snapping fingersâ€™ graphic and liked that it represented taking action quickly. But there was more to consider, like the subtitle, and background color.For a long time, the subtitle was â€œBuild a business so quickly thereâ€™s no time to chicken out.â€ When something in your life has been the same for a while, itâ€™s easy just to leave it as it is. I call this the â€˜Broken Door Problem.â€™ But Iâ€™ve found that the best entrepreneurs stay curious and wonder if things can improve.So I did a poll on both Twitter and my email newsletter, testing different variations. Million Dollar Marketing strategy Part 2 - (continued from Part 1, read that first)Step 3: Break down the goal (by marketing method)In May 2023, 9 months ahead of launch, I planned my marketing strategy (same framework I used at Mint, AppSumo, and YouTube channel).Here are the 5 marketing methods I used: 1- Build a launch team of 1,000 true fans. The advice I got from Tim Ferriss was to involve early readers. People want to be a part of your journey, not just watch from the sidelines.We brought 1,000+ fans into a Slack group and crowdsourced feedback by putting each book chapter into a Google doc where they could leave comments.As the book progressed, we sent out sneak peeks, marketing ideas, and weekly updates. This was by FAR the most helpful strategy to get customer feedback. Once the book launches, I will ask every person for a review.2- Leverage existing assets. Over the past 15 years, Iâ€™ve built assets like my email list and AppSumo.But you donâ€™t need a huge audience. Check the assets you already have, every LinkedIn connection, contact list, friends. There are WAY more people there to help than you realize.Then, give your people an incentive for their support. With Million Dollar Weekend, we are doing book-exclusive incentives. â€œBuy x, get yâ€. â€¢ We researched bonuses that other popular books offeredâ€¢ We ran our incentives by our launch teamâ€¢ We chose bonuses that were both fun and helpful3- Create a Dream 10 list. There were 10 podcasts I wanted to go on that I knew could make a big difference. For each show, I made a list of Q&A's we could cover that would appeal to their specific audience. I also sent title & thumbnail so they could visualize how EASY it would be to have me as a guest. I asked 8 months before launch, followed up, but still faced a lot of rejection. I ended up getting 8 of my Dream 10.4- Work with Prefluencers. I looked for people with niche, rapidly growing audiences in 3 categories: entrepreneurship, real estate, and personal finance. They are easier to get replies from without an existing relationship and their audiences tend to be more engaged.3 ways I found Prefluencers (like Rose Han, Ben Meer, Nick Hutchison):â€¢ Asked my audience for shows I should be onâ€¢ Asked each podcast host after our interviewâ€¢ Googled podcasts similar authors went on for their book tour (like Ali Abdaal)I found 150 people, then reached out asking to give an early copy of my book, collaborate on content, and just connect. Over 50% were excited to be a part of the book (yay!)5- Ask for â€˜Bulk Buysâ€™. It's MUCH easier to sell 1,000 books 1 time than to sell 1 book 1,000 times! I looked up everyone who sponsored my podcast or similar ones, every friend who runs a company or co-working space.Itâ€™s about focusing on high-leverage actions where a bit of effort gets an outsized return.The marketing I did for my book is the SAME method Iâ€™ve used for each of the eight $1M+ businesses Iâ€™ve started. Hope it helps!

Million Dollar Marketing strategy Part 1 -Marketing can be broken down into 3 steps:1- Make a great product.2- Set a clear goal with a timeline.3- Break down the goal (by marketing method).Here's the exact process I used to market my new book Million Dollar Weekend (and how you can apply this strategy to market ANY productâ€¦ itâ€™s what I share in Chapter 8 of my book). Step 1: Make a great book/product.99% of the time people think they have a marketing problem when they have a product problem. When I spoke with best-selling authors like Tim Ferriss, James Clear, Ramit Sethi, they all told me the same thing: The most important marketing strategy is writing a great book. Tactics and gimmicks may work in the short-term, but to be a long-term success, the book has to be great. Word of mouth is the primary driver of sales.How did I make sure Million Dollar Weekend was a product people wanted?â€¢ Wrote a blog post on Tim Ferrissâ€™ site in 2011 that went viralâ€¢ Helped 10,000+ people via my Monthly1K courseâ€¢ Hired my favorite best-selling author, Tahl Razâ€¢ Got feedback on every single word in the book from 1,000+ beta readers â€¢ Ran free weekend cohorts for 6 months helping people take action using the bookEach step was validation that I was on the right track.Step 2: Set clear goals with a timeline.Goals should be exciting enough to get you out of bed in the morning, but realistic enough that you can take action on them. Something I learned from Zuckerberg and use across every one of my businesses is setting ONE clear goal.My #1 goal for this book was to get 1,000 Amazon reviews.To hit this goal, I did 2 things:â€¢ For 2 years, on YouTube office hours, emails, and podcasts I said something like, â€œIf youâ€™re interested in hearing about my book, email meâ€. ~500 emailed and about 75% converted into buyers. â€¢ Then, I posted on Twitter and LinkedIn asking people to DM me or leave a comment if they wanted to join my book launch team. I messaged every single person and asked them to pre-order the book to get access. About 50% said yes.Many entrepreneurs wonâ€™t â€œdo things that donâ€™t scaleâ€ because they think theyâ€™re â€˜aboveâ€™ the 1:1 work. Long-term itâ€™s not scalable (lots of late nights messaging)... BUT I LOVED IT! After we secured the 1,000 reviews, I set a new goal to sell 25,000 books during launch week. I want Million Dollar Weekend to help as many people as it can to start businesses and achieve freedom. And data shows if authors can hit 10,000+ sales, the book will likely gain momentum and sell more. So I wanted to focus mucho attention on getting the book snowball rolling. Hence I initially targeted 10,000 sales. But Ramit told me to â€œdream a little biggerâ€, so I upped my goal to 25,000. This forced me to prioritize high-leverage marketing activities. With 25,000 as the target, we had to work backward to plan HOW to get there...(I'll post Part 2 next!)

I dreamed of working with Tahl Raz for decades. A 21-year-old follower recently messaged me for career advice.Here are 9 pieces of career advice I shared:1. LA.If you canâ€™t be there physically yet, get it online first, eg connecting with people already there.3. Learn outside of your skillset â€” Those who combine multiple skills have enormous leverage. When people get to know and like you online, theyâ€™ll come to you with ideas and even job offers, rather than you begging with a resume.5. Go after the biggest failures â€” You need to push to the point of failure to get the biggest possible growth and learning. For me, almost everything has not worked. But you only need to be right once to build a successful business. Every failure is one step closer to winning.6. The 10 commandments of an entrepreneur (that I live by):1. No codingFigure out if people actually want your service or not BEFORE you put time and money into building it. Validate your ideas first.2. Keep it simpleFocus on the real thing that customers want. Sometimes it's more effective to hand-draw an app on paper vs. taking time and money to build out a full iPhone app.3. Whatâ€™s the problem?Avoid creating a solution for a problem that doesnâ€™t exist. Look for problems before coming up with ideas and work backwards from there to solve them and find your business.4. Find your place on the totem poleThe Totem Pole is how important you are to your customer. A high mark on the totem pole is that the customer really needs you vs. a low mark is a 'nice-to-have.'5. Donâ€™t be needyThis is when you want things like business cards, LLC papers, other useless tools before you can move on. If you want the bells and whistles before you are profitable, youâ€™re adding barriers to yourself and worrying about the wrong thing.6. Maintain momentumThere will be an "aha" moment when people want what you are offering and more often than not, that comes from continually doing at least one small thing each day.7. Use time limitations You will be more creative and save time and money by limiting the time you put into starting your business. Parkinson's Law dictates that a task will swell in perceived importance and complexity in relation to the time allotted for its completion. It is the magic of the imminent deadline.8. Velocity to $1 (This is HUGE)I can remember when I started NinjaCard (a college discount card) and made my first $9 in profit. As I put the discount card in the envelope I recall thinking, â€œIâ€™m actually running my own businessâ€.Once you reduce all barriers and get to your first $1 that will open your eyes and create excitement to continue.9. Handle adversityThere will be a time when you will be challenged; how you persevere is what will separate you from everyone else.10. Do not ignore your fearsRunning a business is daunting. Iâ€™m not here to tell you it wonâ€™t be tough and challenging - it will - but itâ€™s not impossible.
